attributes.title: Does the format use to communicate an intervention’s impact influences how effective the intervention is perceived by teachers?

q1.value: Does the format use to communicate an intervention’s impact influences how effective the intervention is perceived by teachers?

q3.value:
In the last decade, there has been a growing effort to produce high-quality evidence in education (e.g., Lortie-Forgues & Inglis, 2019) and to make this information easily accessible for teachers. For example, the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) in the US and the Education Endowment Foundation (EEF) in the UK have commissioned hundreds of randomised control trials and systematic reviews on the best teaching practices, which have then been summarised on easily accessible platforms (What Works Clearinghouse and EEF Toolkit, respectively). These initiatives have proven very popular; in the UK, almost 60% of senior school leaders report consulting the EEF toolkit to inform their practice (EEF, 2018).
Despite this effort to improve the quality and availability of evidence in education, very little attention has been devoted to evaluating whether the information is presented to teachers in a way that maximises their ability to make informed decisions. 
In educational research, the impact of interventions is typically reported in units of standard deviations (SDs) but is often translated into a more intuitive format when presented to teachers. Many intuitive formats are in use (see Lipsey et al., 2012); for example, the IES tends to report impact in percentile gain and the EEF uses months of progress. In this context, it is important to examine whether these intuitive formats convey the same impressions of the impact of an intervention. It is well known in medical sciences that the format used to communicate binary outcomes (e.g., dead/alive) strongly influences how doctors and patients perceive an intervention’s effectiveness (e.g., McNeil, 1982; Naylor, 1992). Whether such effect exists in education – where most outcomes are continuous (e.g., test scores) – is an important question, as such an effect could interfere with teachers’ ability to make informed decisions about which intervention to use in their classroom.

q4.value:
H1: Teachers’ perceptions of an intervention’s effectiveness is influenced by the format used to report the effect.

H2: Teachers do not perceived the different formats as being equally easy to understand.

H3: Teachers do not perceived the different formats as being equally helpful to judge how effective an intervention is.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
In the survey, teachers will be presented with five vignettes, each describing the impact of a fictitious intervention aimed at improving performance on the KS2 maths test (SAT). Each vignette will describe the intervention’s impact on student performance in a different format (see Qualtrics survey attached below). Not mentioned to the participants, each vignette will describe the same degree of impact (corresponding to an effect of 0.15 SDs). After reading each vignette, participants will be asked: (Q1) How effective do you consider the intervention is at improving performance on the KS2 maths test? (Q2) How easy it is to understand the information given? and (Q3) how useful the information given was to judge the effectiveness of the intervention? (see the specific questions in the survey attached).

Presentation order of the vignettes is randomized for each participant (see survey flow).

q9.value: The presentation order of the vignettes will be randomized for each participant. Randomization will be achieved by Qualtrics' built-in randomizer.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Teachers will be recruited via social media (Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, Instagram). To encourage participation, teachers would be offered a one in twenty chance to win a £30 Amazon voucher. Participants will complete the survey on their computers. Participants must be teachers to participate.

q13.value: We hope to recruit up to 200 participants within two months.

q14.value:
A sample size of 200 will ensure substantial power (>90%) to detect a relatively small within-subject effect (f = 0.15).
library('WebPower')
wp.rmanova(n = (200*5), ng = 1, nm = 5, f = 0.15, nscor = 0.7, alpha = 0.05, type = 1)

Moreover, sample of that size will also provide considerable accuracy in the measurement of teachers' judgments. Ratings are made on 7-points scales. Based on a pilot study (n = 60) of the same questionnaire where the SD of teachers’ judgment ratings was 1.45, we expect the 95% confidence interval surrounding teachers’ ratings to be ± 0.20 points, that is ± 3% of a 7-point scale (i.e., 1.96*1.45/sqrt(200)).

q15.value: If we have not reached 200 participants with usable data by month 2, we will continue recruiting for 4 more months until we have at least 100 participants. If we are not able to recruit 100 participants after 6 total months, we will stop data collection.

question.value: Participants will be presented with the effect of interventions in five different formats (order is random). This is a within-subject design. All the effects described in the vignettes correspond to an effect size of 0.15 SDs. The specific wording used for each format is in the Qualtric survey attached.

After reading each vignette, participants will be asked: 
(Q1) How effective do you consider the intervention is at improving performance on the KS2 maths test? 
(Q2) How easy to understand the information presented was.
(Q3) how helpful the information presented was to judge how effective the intervention.

In addition, demographic variables will be measure, as well as participants familiarity with the concept of effect size, familiarity with the KS2 maths test and their maths ability. See attached Qualtric survey for the specific questions asked and their exact wording.

To evaluate our hypotheses, we will use mixed effect models with random intercepts (see R code below). A significant test will indicate support for the hypothesis.


#Hypothesis 1
#PerceivedEff <- numerical variable, range 1 to 7
#Format <- factor with 5 levels (corresponding to 5 different formats)
#ID <- factor with n levels (corresponding to n participants)
library('lme4')
fit.format = lmer(PerceivedEff ~ format + (1|ID), data = dat, REML=FALSE)
fit.null = lmer(PerceivedEff ~ (1|ID), data = dat, REML=FALSE)
anova(fit.null,fit.format)


#Hypothesis 2
#PerceivedEasy <- numerical variable, range 1 to 7
#Format <- factor with 5 levels (corresponding to 5 different formats)
#ID <- factor with n levels (corresponding to n participants)
library('lme4')
fit.format = lmer(PerceivedEasy ~ format + (1|ID), data = dat, REML=FALSE)
fit.null = lmer(PerceivedEasy ~ (1|ID), data = dat, REML=FALSE)
anova(fit.null,fit.format)



#Hypothesis 3
#PerceivedHelp <- numerical variable, range 1 to 7
#Format <- factor with 5 levels (corresponding to 5 different formats)
#ID <- factor with n levels (corresponding to n participants)
library('lme4')
fit.format = lmer(PerceivedHelp ~ format + (1|ID), data = dat, REML=FALSE)
fit.null = lmer(PerceivedHelp ~ (1|ID), data = dat, REML=FALSE)
anova(fit.null,fit.format)

q21.value: All statistical tests will use an alpha value of .05.

q22.value:
Participants who do not fully answer the questionnaire will be excluded. 
Participants who are not teachers will be excluded

q24.value:
We will conduct a exploratory analysis to determine:

Whether perceived effectiveness (averaged across the five formats) is related to teacher’s demographic variables, familiarity with KS2 Maths test or self-reported Maths ability.

Whether within-teacher variation to their responses to the different formats (as measured by absolute variation around a teachers’ mean rating) is related to teachers’ demographic variables, familiarity with KS2 Maths test or self-reported Maths ability.

Whether teacher’s responses vary based on the medium through which they accessed the survey.

We do not have any clear hypotheses about the outcomes of these analyses. 
 
As a robustness check, we will report estimates from the first format that each teacher saw. This analysis will produce less precise estimates, but they will be less susceptible to testing effects. Because we do not have strong hypotheses about the direction of any testing effect, we expect these estimates to be similar (if less precisely estimated) to those outlined in our preregistered analysis.

attributes.title: Incidence of Medical Reversal in American Heart Association and European Society of Cardiology guidelines over the last two decades.
attributes.description: This is a descriptive comparative study between published and re-published guidelines in the last 20 years, under the seal of the American Heart Association (AHA) and the European Society of Cardiology (ESC), in search of the prevalence of medical reversals.

q1.value: Incidence of Medical Reversal in American Heart Association guidelines over the last two decades.

q2.value: Daniel Oliveira Medina da Silva, Alessandra Carvalho Caldas, Luis Correia

q3.value: Medical Reversal (MR) is a phenomenon characterized by the scientific discovery that a recommended or established medical practice is not beneficial, through a new scientific evidence with better design, controls, sizes and outcomes, making the practice no longer recommended. Its main consequence is the possible harms to patients. We aim to identify MRs in Guidelines of Cardiology of the American Heart Association published over the last two decades.

q4.value:
Describe the incidence of medical reversal among recommendations related to Coronary Artery Disease in AHA/ACC guidelines; 
Test the hypothesis that a low level of evidence predispose to medical reversal.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
It is a metascience design. Descriptive and analytic from a metascience observation. 
Cohort study having guidelines’ recomendations as units of observation to evaluate survival of recommendations over follow-up.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The two most recent versions of ACC/AHA Guidelines related to coronary artery disease and published between 2000 and 2019 will be selected by searching in the official site of the American Heart Association. Guidelines is defined as documents that include recommendations organized by CORs and LOEs, clearly highlighted and separated from the rest of the text. Expert consensus, performance measures, adequacy criteria and focused updates will not be considered guidelines.  
The most recent guideline and its predecessor will be pared for comparison. Initially, all class I and II recommendations for testing or treatment in the first guideline will be listed. Secondly, each of these recommendations will be searched in the second guideline. Those recommendations who did not survive over time will be defined as “tentative medical reversal”. Thirdly, tentative reversals will lead to search of medical literature, using the PICO method, in order to find justification for the recent desapearing of the recommendation. Definitive medical reversal will be defined when a new evidence, superior to its predecessors by virtue of precision and risk of bias contradicts the first recommendation. These three steps will be perfomed by a single investigator and adjucated by a second. In case of discordance, opinions will be aligned by matters of discussion.
Each original recommendation will have its level of evidence recorded.

q14.value: All guidelines published and with new published versions by AHA between 2000 and 2019 will be included.

question.value:
The outcome variable will be medical reversal.
Characteristics of the recommendations, such as level of evidence as defined by the guideline, diagnosis/treatment recommendatoin, clinical/invasive procedure, acute/chronic condition will be recorded.

Incidence of medical reversal will be described as proportion of recommendations and 95% confidence interval.  The proportion of medical revesal will be compared among level A, B and C of evidence by chi-squared test, and adjusted for other characteristics by logistic regressoin.

q21.value: All proportions will be calculated though a 95% confidence interval. A p value of 0.05 will be considered for all the tests. Will be used a two-tailed test for each analysis.

q1.value: Can Social Media Harm Women Body Image - High Ecological Examination Study of Instagram effects on body image and mood

q3.value: The aim of the current study is to examine the effects of using Instagram on women body image under an ecological setting. Instagram is a popular image-based social media platform. Previous empirical findings demonstrated repeatedly that exposing women to screenshots of images depicting the thin-ideal female body taken from Instagram cause a feeling of body dissatisfaction. However, despite yielding consistent findings the methodology employed by these studies contains a major limitation. They suffer from low ecological validity because in these studies participants are exposed to a set of pre-selected Instagram photos on a controlled computer presentation, a method that does not simulate the fashion in which people actually use Instagram in their daily life. In real-life, users use their account freely (typically via a mobile device), browsing the feed and seeing 'stories' posted by the accounts they follow. Accordingly, the experience of viewing pre-selected photos cannot be considered to credibly reflect the typical experience of using Instagram. Therefore, the objective of this study is to provide a more ecological examination of the effects of Instagram on women body image. Specifically, a randomized controlled study is carried out in a non-clinical sample of female participants. After providing informed consent, all participants will be asked complete the first part of the evaluation that will include a demographic survey, trait body-image related measures (BIDQ, BAS-2, PASTAS-trait, DASS-D, and SISE).Following the completion of these trait measures at baseline, participants will be randomized to one of two conditions: (1) the typical thin-ideal Instagram condition; and (2) the Placebo Instagram condition. Since, it’s highly likely to anticipate the existence of a vast variance in the range of content different Instagram users would get exposed to when browsing the platform using their own personal account. Rather than asking participants to log into their own personal account, participants in each condition will instead log-into one out of two Instagram accounts in accordance to their assigned condition. The photos will appear in the account of the thin-ideal Instagram condition will be mainly of attractive peers (i.e., female undergraduate students), attractive celebrities (e.g. Kim Kardashian, Beyoncé, Neta Alchimister, and Gal Gadot), and prevalent social media imagery referred to as “thinspiration” (i.e., “thin” + “inspiration”), that glorifies weight loss and disordered eating. In contrast, the photos that will appear in the account of the placebo Instagram condition will be mainly emotionally neutral (e.g., traveling and nature photos, architecture photos, ‘innocuous’ (unsexual) memes, and photos of cars). After the 10-min exposure, participants in both conditions will be requested to provide a response indicating the degree of similarity (on a 1-10 scale) in content when comparing it to the content she usually sees while using her personal social media account. Immediately following providing the response, all of the participants will complete the state measures (appearance satisfaction, negative mood, PASTAS-state), which are able to indicate how participants they feel ‘right now’ about their body, and are more suitable to study the effects of specific stimuli or manipulations in an experimental situation.

q4.value:
Hypotheses
(a) We predict that, in comparison to the placebo Instagram condition, participants in the thin-ideal Instagram condition will report a more negative state body-image measures: including lower appearance satisfaction and more anxiety about specific body parts, as well as higher negative mood. 
(b) We predict that Instagram similarity score, Instagram condition, the interaction between Instagram similarity and condition, and body appreciation would all emerge as significant unique predictors of appearance satisfaction after accounting for each other and for self-reported BID (body image disturbance). We also predict that Instagram similarity score, Instagram condition, the interaction between Instagram similarity and condition, and body appreciation would all emerge as significant unique predictors of negative mood after accounting for each other and for self-esteem and depression. Finally, we predict that Instagram similarity score, Instagram condition, and the interaction between Instagram similarity and condition, would all emerge as significant unique predictors of state anxiety about specific body parts after accounting for each other and for trait anxiety about specific body parts.
(c) We hypothesize that relatively to the placebo Instagram, participants exposed to the thin-ideal Instagram will rate it as significantly more similar to their own personal account.
(d) We anticipate finding a positive zero-order correlation between daily time using Instagram and body image disturbance beliefs and symptoms and trait anxiety about specific body parts. We also anticipate finding a negative zero-order correlation between daily time using Instagram and positive body attitudes.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value:
a double blind procedure would take place in this study. 
Following the completion of trait measures, the  participants, which are in this stage of the study still not allocated to a specific experimental condition,  will call the research assistant (RA) back into the lab room. The RA will explain the instructions for using Instagram and provide them with an iPad opened on the Instagram log-in page. Then, immediately after the RA leaves the room, the Qualtrics online platform will randomly assign participants into one of two conditions by providing them with different login information (i.e., username and password) to an Instagram account in accordance to their assigned condition. 

The participants they will not know the condition to which they have been assigned. And the experimenter can only possibly become aware of condition allocation only after each participant had completed the entire study.

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor (Instagram condition) and 2 levels (1. the typical thin-ideal Instagram condition; and 2. the Placebo Instagram condition).

q9.value: The randomization to the two experimental conditions will be done automatically via Qualtrics  and carried out in a 1:1 ratio.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
Female participants will be recruited through the college online SONA system. Participants will earn 2 course credits for agreeing to participate and completing the study. The Study SONA will direct participants to schedule an appointment for a lab session to complete the study.  
In the lab participants will complete the measures on the lab computer (via Qualtrics platform).
 
Eligibility requirements: Participants must be
•	Female 
•	Age 18 or older
•	Have an active Instagram or Facebook account (an active account is defined as an account the participant had used at least once during the following month).

q13.value: Our target sample size is 180 participants (at least 150 participants, no more than a 200 participants).

q15.value:
We will terminate enrollment for new participants immediately after we will reach a sample size of 180 participants. 
(By removing the study advertisement from the SONA website)

question.value: We manipulated the Instagram condition (for more details see Study Information - Description).

Body Image Disturbance Questionnaire (BIDQ; Cash et al., 2004)  
The BIDQ is a 7-item screening measure for body image disturbance. Participants are requested to indicate their degree of concern or preoccupation with their physical appearance, their appearance-related distress and the effects of body image concerns on various aspects of functioning on a 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely) scale. Higher scores indicate higher body image disturbance. The BIDQ has been extensively validated and found to be reliable in both clinical and nonclinical samples. 
The Body Appreciation Scale 2 (BAS-2; Tylka & Wood-Barcalow, 2015a)
The BAS-2 is a 10-item self-report measure of positive body image rated on a 1 (never) to 5 (always) scale, that was revised from the BAS (Avalos, Tylka, & Wood-Barcalow, 2005). Scores on the 10 items are averaged; higher scores reflect greater body appreciation. The BAS-2 has demonstrated internal consistency, construct validity, and 20-day test-retest reliability (Tracy L. Tylka & Wood-Barcalow, 2015a). 
The Single-Item Self-Esteem Scale (SISE; Robins, Hendin, & Trzesniewski, 2001)
Participants rate the extent to which the statement “I have high self-esteem" is descriptive of them on a 9-point scale. The SISE has been found to have high test-retest reliability and strong criterion validity (Robins et al., 2001). 
The short version of the depression, anxiety, stress scale (DASS-D; Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995)
The DASS is a valid and reliable 21-items self-report questionnaire listing negative emotional symptoms (depression, anxiety, and stress). Participants rate the extent to which they felt depression, anxiety, and stress in thr past week on a 4-point scale, ranging from 0 (did not apply to me at all) to 3 (applied to me very much or most of the time). In the present study, only the depression scale (7 items) is used. 
The Physical Appearance State and Trait Anxiety Scale – trait version (PASTAS-T; Reed, Thompson, Brannick, & Sacco, 1991) 
The PASTAS-T is a reliable and valid 15-item self-report that measures the extent to which participants generally feel (trait) anxious about specific body parts (hips, waist, legs, arms), on a 5-point scale from 1 (never) to 5 (always). Higher scores indicate higher physical appearance anxiety. 
The Physical Appearance State and Trait Anxiety Scale – state version (PASTAS-S; Reed et al., 1991)
The PASTAS-S is a reliable and valid 15-item self-report that measures the extent to which participants currently feel (state) anxious about specific body parts on a 5-point scale from 0 (not at all) to 4 (exceptionally so). This self-report indicates how participants feel 'right now' about their body and is more suitable to study the effects of specific stimuli or manipulations in an experimental situation (Thompson, Burke, & Krawczyk, 2012). In this study, PASTAS-S was measured following the using Instagram. 
Appearance satisfaction 
State appearance satisfaction was assessed immediately following the Instagram resilience task (see below) using four Visual Analogue Scales (VAS; see Heinberg & Thompson,1995 and Tiggemann & Zaccardo, 2015 for similar methodologies). End-points on each VAS were labelled “not at all” and “extremely”. Participants indicated their feelings 'right now' by moving a marker to any point along a 10cm horizontal line. The four VASs (satisfaction scores on weight, overall appearance, body shape, and face and hair) will be averaged to create a body satisfaction score. Higher scores indicate higher body satisfaction. 
Negative mood 
State negative mood was measured immediately following the Instagram resilience task using five VASs asking participants to report on how anxious, depressed, angry, happy, and confident they were feeling 'right now’ (See Heinberg & Thompson, 1995 and Tiggemann & Zaccardo, 2015). Scores will be averaged (with the two positive mood scales 'happy' and 'confident' reversed) to create a negative mood score, with higher scores indicating increased negative mood.

The four Appearance satisfaction VASs (satisfaction scores on weight, overall appearance, body shape, and face and hair) will be averaged to create a body satisfaction score. Higher scores indicate higher body satisfaction 

The five negative mood Scores will be averaged (with the two positive mood 'happy' and 'confident' scales reversed) to create a negative mood score, with higher scores indicating increased negative mood.

Descriptive statistics were used to report means, standard deviations and t-tests were and χ 2 will be used to assess differences between groups in demographic variables, and symptom measures (BIDQ, BAS-2, PASTAS, SISE and DASS). A series of univariate analysis of variance (ANOVA) with Bonferroni adjustments will be conducted in order to carefully examine any differences between the two experimental conditions. A series of one-way ANOVAs with Condition as the between-subject factor (thin-ideal/placebo), will be conducted to analyze each state measures (i.e., appearance satisfaction, negative mood, and PASTAS-S). An independent t-test will be calculated to examine differences between the two conditions on the degree on Instagram similarity scores.  Then to test our second hypothesis, we tested three standard multiple regression (i.e., simultaneous linear regression) models. The first model will predict appearance satisfaction as a function of Instagram similarity scores, Instagram condition (dummy variable), the interaction between Instagram similarity and condition, BAS-2 scores, and BIDQ scores. The second model will predict negative mood as a function of Instagram similarity scores, Instagram condition (dummy variable), the interaction between Instagram similarity and condition, BAS-2 scores, SISE and DASS-D. The third model will predict PASTAS-state as a function of Instagram similarity scores, Instagram condition (dummy variable), the interaction between Instagram similarity and condition, and PASTAS-T.

registration_responses.q1: Can Social Media Harm Women Body Image - High Ecological Examination Study of Instagram effects on body image and mood
registration_responses.q3: The aim of the current study is to examine the effects of using Instagram on women body image under an ecological setting. Instagram is a popular image-based social media platform. Previous empirical findings demonstrated repeatedly that exposing women to screenshots of images depicting the thin-ideal female body taken from Instagram cause a feeling of body dissatisfaction. However, despite yielding consistent findings the methodology employed by these studies contains a major limitation. They suffer from low ecological validity because in these studies participants are exposed to a set of pre-selected Instagram photos on a controlled computer presentation, a method that does not simulate the fashion in which people actually use Instagram in their daily life. In real-life, users use their account freely (typically via a mobile device), browsing the feed and seeing 'stories' posted by the accounts they follow. Accordingly, the experience of viewing pre-selected photos cannot be considered to credibly reflect the typical experience of using Instagram. Therefore, the objective of this study is to provide a more ecological examination of the effects of Instagram on women body image. Specifically, a randomized controlled study is carried out in a non-clinical sample of female participants. After providing informed consent, all participants will be asked complete the first part of the evaluation that will include a demographic survey, trait body-image related measures (BIDQ, BAS-2, PASTAS-trait, DASS-D, and SISE).Following the completion of these trait measures at baseline, participants will be randomized to one of two conditions: (1) the typical thin-ideal Instagram condition; and (2) the Placebo Instagram condition. Since, it’s highly likely to anticipate the existence of a vast variance in the range of content different Instagram users would get exposed to when browsing the platform using their own personal account. Rather than asking participants to log into their own personal account, participants in each condition will instead log-into one out of two Instagram accounts in accordance to their assigned condition. The photos will appear in the account of the thin-ideal Instagram condition will be mainly of attractive peers (i.e., female undergraduate students), attractive celebrities (e.g. Kim Kardashian, Beyoncé, Neta Alchimister, and Gal Gadot), and prevalent social media imagery referred to as “thinspiration” (i.e., “thin” + “inspiration”), that glorifies weight loss and disordered eating. In contrast, the photos that will appear in the account of the placebo Instagram condition will be mainly emotionally neutral (e.g., traveling and nature photos, architecture photos, ‘innocuous’ (unsexual) memes, and photos of cars). After the 10-min exposure, participants in both conditions will be requested to provide a response indicating the degree of similarity (on a 1-10 scale) in content when comparing it to the content she usually sees while using her personal social media account. Immediately following providing the response, all of the participants will complete the state measures (appearance satisfaction, negative mood, PASTAS-state), which are able to indicate how participants they feel ‘right now’ about their body, and are more suitable to study the effects of specific stimuli or manipulations in an experimental situation.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypotheses
(a) We predict that, in comparison to the placebo Instagram condition, participants in the thin-ideal Instagram condition will report a more negative state body-image measures: including lower appearance satisfaction and more anxiety about specific body parts, as well as higher negative mood. 
(b) We predict that Instagram similarity score, Instagram condition, the interaction between Instagram similarity and condition, and body appreciation would all emerge as significant unique predictors of appearance satisfaction after accounting for each other and for self-reported BID (body image disturbance). We also predict that Instagram similarity score, Instagram condition, the interaction between Instagram similarity and condition, and body appreciation would all emerge as significant unique predictors of negative mood after accounting for each other and for self-esteem and depression. Finally, we predict that Instagram similarity score, Instagram condition, and the interaction between Instagram similarity and condition, would all emerge as significant unique predictors of state anxiety about specific body parts after accounting for each other and for trait anxiety about specific body parts.
(c) We hypothesize that relatively to the placebo Instagram, participants exposed to the thin-ideal Instagram will rate it as significantly more similar to their own personal account.
(d) We anticipate finding a positive zero-order correlation between daily time using Instagram and body image disturbance beliefs and symptoms and trait anxiety about specific body parts. We also anticipate finding a negative zero-order correlation between daily time using Instagram and positive body attitudes.

registration_responses.q17.question:
Body Image Disturbance Questionnaire (BIDQ; Cash et al., 2004)  
The BIDQ is a 7-item screening measure for body image disturbance. Participants are requested to indicate their degree of concern or preoccupation with their physical appearance, their appearance-related distress and the effects of body image concerns on various aspects of functioning on a 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely) scale. Higher scores indicate higher body image disturbance. The BIDQ has been extensively validated and found to be reliable in both clinical and nonclinical samples. 
The Body Appreciation Scale 2 (BAS-2; Tylka & Wood-Barcalow, 2015a)
The BAS-2 is a 10-item self-report measure of positive body image rated on a 1 (never) to 5 (always) scale, that was revised from the BAS (Avalos, Tylka, & Wood-Barcalow, 2005). Scores on the 10 items are averaged; higher scores reflect greater body appreciation. The BAS-2 has demonstrated internal consistency, construct validity, and 20-day test-retest reliability (Tracy L. Tylka & Wood-Barcalow, 2015a). 
The Single-Item Self-Esteem Scale (SISE; Robins, Hendin, & Trzesniewski, 2001)
Participants rate the extent to which the statement “I have high self-esteem" is descriptive of them on a 9-point scale. The SISE has been found to have high test-retest reliability and strong criterion validity (Robins et al., 2001). 
The short version of the depression, anxiety, stress scale (DASS-D; Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995)
The DASS is a valid and reliable 21-items self-report questionnaire listing negative emotional symptoms (depression, anxiety, and stress). Participants rate the extent to which they felt depression, anxiety, and stress in thr past week on a 4-point scale, ranging from 0 (did not apply to me at all) to 3 (applied to me very much or most of the time). In the present study, only the depression scale (7 items) is used. 
The Physical Appearance State and Trait Anxiety Scale – trait version (PASTAS-T; Reed, Thompson, Brannick, & Sacco, 1991) 
The PASTAS-T is a reliable and valid 15-item self-report that measures the extent to which participants generally feel (trait) anxious about specific body parts (hips, waist, legs, arms), on a 5-point scale from 1 (never) to 5 (always). Higher scores indicate higher physical appearance anxiety. 
The Physical Appearance State and Trait Anxiety Scale – state version (PASTAS-S; Reed et al., 1991)
The PASTAS-S is a reliable and valid 15-item self-report that measures the extent to which participants currently feel (state) anxious about specific body parts on a 5-point scale from 0 (not at all) to 4 (exceptionally so). This self-report indicates how participants feel 'right now' about their body and is more suitable to study the effects of specific stimuli or manipulations in an experimental situation (Thompson, Burke, & Krawczyk, 2012). In this study, PASTAS-S was measured following the using Instagram.

State appearance satisfaction was assessed immediately following the Instagram resilience task (see below) using four Visual Analogue Scales (VAS; see Heinberg & Thompson,1995 and Tiggemann & Zaccardo, 2015 for similar methodologies). End-points on each VAS were labelled “not at all” and “extremely”. Participants indicated their feelings 'right now' by moving a marker to any point along a 10cm horizontal line. The four VASs (satisfaction scores on weight, overall appearance, body shape, and face and hair) will be averaged to create a body satisfaction score. Higher scores indicate higher body satisfaction. 
Negative mood 
State negative mood was measured immediately following the Instagram resilience task using five VASs asking participants to report on how anxious, depressed, angry, happy, and confident they were feeling 'right now’ (See Heinberg & Thompson, 1995 and Tiggemann & Zaccardo, 2015). Scores will be averaged (with the two positive mood scales 'happy' and 'confident' reversed) to create a negative mood score, with higher scores indicating increased negative mood.

attributes.title: Eating Disorders amongst Indigenous-Australians and evidence for diagnostic and screening tools, a Scoping Review Protocol

summary.value:
Background 
Indigenous-Australians have resided on the Australian continent for at least 60000 years. They are also known as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and First-Australians. Indigenous-Australians also use unique local terms to describe their people depending on their tribal group, family or region. 
Eating disorders are mental illnesses in which people experience severe disturbances in their eating behaviour and related thoughts and emotions (termed disordered eating). People with eating disorders typically become pre-occupied with food and their weight or body image. These disorders include the most lethal mental illness: Anorexia Nervosa (AN), as well as Bulimia Nervosa (BN), Binge Eating Disorder (BED), Avoidant Restrictive Feeding and Eating Disorder (ARFID) and Other Specified Feeding and Eating Disorders (OSFED). (1) Recent research has suggested that eating disorders are more common amongst Indigenous-Australians compared other Australians, including adolescents and adults. (2, 3) Recent research into mental illnesses amongst Indigenous-Australians suggest there is a dearth of evidence addressing eating disorders in this population. (4)
The aim of this review is to establish the extent of published research on this topic, including screening or diagnostic tools for the assessment of eating disorders and disordered eating amongst Indigenous-Australians.
Review question/s:	
1.	What is the volume and content of literature on eating disorders and disordered eating amongst Indigenous-Australians?
2.	Has a screening or diagnostic tool/Instrument been developed for the assessment of eating disorders amongst Indigenous-Australians? 
Methods
We will use the 6-stage framework for scoping reviews described by Arskey and O’Malley: identify the research question, identify relevant studies by searching databases, select studies, chart the data; collate, summarise and report the results. We will also undertake the additional step suggested by Arskey and O’Malley of consultation of the findings, in our case with other eating disorder experts, local Aboriginal Medical Services as well as Indigenous Australian community members and other Indigenous Academics. (5) We will use reporting items as suggested by the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR) Checklist. (6)

Ethics and dissemination
Data will be extracted from published materials, therefore ethics approval is not required. The review will be submitted to a peer reviewed journal and presented at relevant conferences. When published provided to those involved in the consultation process. 

References 
1.	Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5): American Psychiatric Association 2013.
2.	Burt A, Mannan H, Touyz S, Hay P. Prevalence and Features of Eating Disorders amongst Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.  Australia and New Zealand Academy for Eating Disorders (ANZAED) conference 2019; August; Adelaide, Australia.2019.
3.	Burt A, Mitchison D, Dale E, Bussey K, Trompeter N, Lonergan A, et al. Prevalence, Features and Health Impacts of Eating Disorders amongst First-Australian Yiramarang (Adolescents) and in comparison with Other Australian Adolescents (accepted in press). Journal of Eating Disorders 2020.
4.	Black EB, Ranmuthugala G, Kondalsamy-Chennakesavan S, Toombs MR, Nicholson GC, Kisely S. A systematic review: Identifying the prevalence rates of psychiatric disorder in Australia’s indigenous populations. Australian and New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry. 2015;49(5):412-29.
5.	Arksey H, O'Malley L. Scoping studies: towards a methodological framework. International Journal of Social Research Methodology. 2005;8(1):19-32.
6.	Tricco AC, Lillie E, Zarin W, O'Brien KK, Colquhoun H, Levac D, et al. PRISMA Extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR): Checklist and Explanation. Annals of Internal Medicine. 2018;169(7):467-73.

name.value: Suitability of speeded response tasks for within-subject designs.

other.value: This pilot study will inform the design of a larger study which will be pre-registered under the same project.

sample.value: N = 40.  As previous studies have used a between-subjects design, we have no prior research on which to estimate an effect size.  As our participants are undergraduate students receiving course credit, the choice of sample size was determined by the need to balance available resources (allocation of credit points) with as large a sample as possible to ensure meaningful results.

analyses.value:
As we are only interested in the difference in un-speeded accuracy between the two presentation orders, three independent sample t-tests will be conducted:

1. Test statements: un-speeded first presentation vs. un-speeded second presentation.
2. True controls: un-speeded first presentation vs. un-speeded second presentation.
3. False controls: un-speeded first presentation vs. un-speeded second presentation.

outliers.value: Following Kelemen et al. (2013), participants with less than 80% accuracy on control statements in the un-speeded condition, and those who fail to answer more than 75% of test statements in the speeded condition, will be excluded from analysis.

dependent.value: Accuracy: The dependent variable is accuracy in responding to a series of 98 statements.  Correct responses are coded 1 and incorrect responses are coded 0, such that higher scores represent more accurate responding.

conditions.value:
Statement-type: The 98 statements are of six types: biological teleological test, natural non-living teleological test, true teleological control, true causal control, false teleological control, and false causal control.  For the purposes of this study, these six statement types will be collapsed into three types: test, true control, false control.

Speed: Participants will respond to the same 98 statements under two conditions (speeded, un-speeded).

Order: The order of the conditions will be counterbalanced, such that half the participants receive the speeded condition first, and half receive the un-speeded condition first.

hypothesis.value:
Speeded responding has previously been used as a method for measuring implicitly held beliefs, as it reduces the opportunity to engage effortful thought needed to inhibit a first response (e.g., Kelemen, Rottman, and Seston, 2013).  However, as previous studies using speeded vs. un-speeded responding have employed a between-subjects design, the purpose of this pilot study is to determine whether this paradigm can be administered in a within-subjects design.  

In this pilot study, participants will respond “true” or “false” to a series of statements under two conditions (speeded, un-speeded).  It is reasonable to expect that if the same items are presented first in an un-speeded condition and then in a speeded condition, the familiarity from the initial exposure to these items may make speeded responding easier than it would otherwise be.  However, what is less clear is whether un-speeded response accuracy will differ when this precedes a speeded condition, compared to when it follows a speeded condition.  It is possible, for example, that if participants are administered the speeded condition first, they may be motivated to respond consistently in the second (un-speeded) condition.

The results of this pilot study will inform the design of a larger laboratory-based study.  If response accuracy in the un-speeded condition does not differ according to the order of presentation, in the full study, the speeded condition will always be presented first.  However, if response accuracy in the un-speeded condition does differ according to the order of presentation, in the full study, the order of conditions will either be randomised, with “order” included as a variable in all relevant analyses, or we will employ a between-subjects design.

The results of this pilot study will inform the design of a larger laboratory-based study.  If response accuracy in the un-speeded condition does not differ according to the order of presentation, in the full study, the speeded condition will always be presented first.  However, if response accuracy in the un-speeded condition does differ according to the order of presentation, in the full study, the order of conditions will either be randomised, with “order” included as a variable in all relevant analyses, or we will employ a between-subjects design.

attributes.title: School closure experiment with cognitive load manipulation

q1.value: The effect of cognitive load on school closure experiment.

q3.value: There is strong evidence that giving the probabilistic forecasts in addition to deterministic forecasts can help people make better quality decisions. Since it is giving additional information, the probabilistic forecasts may not be as helpful in a more cognitively challenging situation as it is in a simpler situation. This study aims to see the effect of cognitive load on the effect of the probabilistic forecast.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Challengingness
Hypothesis 1a: Forecast Format
The conditions with both probabilistic forecast (percent chance for a certain amount of snow accumulation) and deterministic forecast (single value estimate of snow accumulation) will be considered more challenging than deterministic forecast only condition because they contain more information to be processed. 

Hypothesis 1b: Number of Options
The conditions with 3-options (Stay Open vs. Delay 1 Hour vs. Close) will be perceived to be more challenging than the conditions with 2-option (Stay Open vs. Close) because there are more alternatives to evaluate. 

Hypothesis 1c: Interaction
There may be an interaction such that the combination of 3-options and probabilistic information is rated as particularly challenging (greater impact of probabilistic on 3-options).  

(Conditional hypotheses 1d & 1e - if the first measure of challengingness turns out to be different from the other two challengingness measures)
Hypothesis 1d: Challengingness – Number of Options (before the first decision is made) 
The condition with 3-option (Stay Open vs. Delay 1 Hour vs. Close) will be perceived to be more challenging than the condition with 2-option (Stay Open vs. Close) because there are more alternatives to evaluate, without any possible effect of decision and outcome. 

Hypothesis 1e: Challengingness – Forecast Format (before the first decision is made)
The condition with both probabilistic forecast (percent chance for a certain amount of snow accumulation) and deterministic forecast (single value estimate of snow accumulation) will be considered more challenging than deterministic forecast only condition because it contains more information to process, without any possible effect of decision and outcome.

Hypothesis 2: Decision quality operationalized as remaining points
Hypothesis 2a: Forecast Format
There will be more points left in the conditions with probabilistic forecast and deterministic forecast than in the conditions with only deterministic forecast, indicating the better decision quality for probabilistic forecast and deterministic forecast condition. 

Hypothesis 2b: Number of Options
There will be more points left in the conditions with 2-option than in the 3-option conditions, showing better decision quality when choices are simpler. 

Hypothesis 2c: Interaction
There may be an interaction such that the advantage for the probabilistic forecast is not seen in the 3-options condition (no increase in points) due to higher information processing load.  


Hypothesis 3: Decision quality seen by the expected value
Hypothesis 3a: Forecast Format
There will be higher expected value in conditions with probabilistic forecast and deterministic forecast than in deterministic only condition, indicating better decision quality for probabilistic forecast condition. 

Hypothesis 3b: Number of Options
There will be higher expected values in 2-option conditions than in 3-option conditions, indicating better quality when choices are simpler. 

Hypothesis 3c: Interaction
There may be an interaction such that there is no advantage for probabilistic forecasts in the 3-options condition due to higher information processing load.  


Hypothesis 4: Trust
Hypothesis 4a: Forecast Format 
The trust ratings (before making a decision, after the outcome, at the end) will be higher in the conditions with the probabilistic forecasts in addition to deterministic forecast than in deterministic forecast only condition.

Hypothesis 4b: Number of Options 
The trust ratings (before making a decision, after the outcome, at the end) may be higher in the conditions with 2-option than in 3-option because there are more possibilities of penalties in 3-option conditions. 

Hypothesis 4c: Interaction
There may be an interaction such that there is no advantage for the probabilistic forecast in the 3-option due to more chances of penalties.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The experiment will be a 2(forecast format) by 2(number of options) between-groups design. Forecast format will have two levels, one level with deterministic forecast alone and the other level with the probabilistic forecasts in addition to the deterministic forecast. The number of options also has two levels. It will vary with either two-option or three-option. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the four resulting conditions.

question.value:
The participants will be recruited through the Psychology research pool system at the University of Washington. The participants will be undergraduate students at the University of Washington. The participants need to be18 years old or older to be able to sign up for the participation of the experiment. Participants will earn course credit and have the opportunity to earn a cash reward commensurate with their performance. 

When participants come to the computer lab, they will be seated at individual computer stations. Then, they will read and sign the paper consent form and enter gender and age, which will be recorded under each participant number. Next, participants will read the instructions on the computer monitor while the experimenter reads them aloud, which includes the task scenario and the cost-loss structure. Participants are to assume the role of decision consultant and to give advice about which action to take for schools in different districts faced with possible snowstorms. 

The format of the weather forecast and the number of decision-options will be varied across conditions. About half of the participants will be assigned to conditions with a single value forecast (deterministic forecast) for snow accumulation. The other half of the participants will be assigned to conditions with percent chance (probabilistic forecast) for snow accumulation exceeding specified amounts in addition to a single value forecast. 

Moreover, about half of the participants will be assigned to a 3-option condition, and the other half will be assigned to a 2-option condition. 
3 Option
In the 3-option condition, there will be 3 possible options of staying open, delaying one hour, and closing. The participants will be told to advise closing if they expect the snow to accumulate six inches or more the next day, advise delaying one hour if they expect the snow to accumulate more than one inch but less than six inches the next day, and advise staying open if they expect the snow to accumulate less than one inch the next day. 
2 Option
In the 2-option condition, participants will choose between staying open and closing for the day. The participants will be told to advise closing if they expect the snow to accumulate six inches or more the next day and to advise staying open if they expect the snow to accumulate less than six inches. 

Participants will be asked to provide advice on 61 trials representing different school districts and different days from mid-November to mid-March for four hypothetical winter seasons. Each forecast (for Tuesday) will be issued on Monday, and the decision will be made on Monday for Tuesday. Different school districts will be used to encourage participants to consider each trial to be independent. 

In order to motivate participants to do their best, they will be provided with a point balance and be told to retain as many points as possible. Giving the advice to close the school costs two points to cover for makeup days, giving the advice to delay the school for one-hour costs one point to cover for makeup classes, and giving the advice to stay open costs zero points. However, when the participant gives the advice to stay open or delay one hour and six or more inches of snow is observed the next day, the participant will be penalized eight points to reflect severe traffic accidents and injuries. In the three option condition, when the participant gives the advice to stay open and more than one inch of snow but less than six inches of snow is observed the next day, the participant will be penalized two points to reflect less severe traffic accidents and injuries. 

To further motivate participants to put forward their best effort, $1 cash will be rewarded for every 5 points above 118 points. This threshold was chosen to discourage the simplistic but unrealistic strategy of closing schools on all trials, which leads to the final balance of 118 points in the 3-option condition. The threshold for the cash reward was held constant across conditions. It was based on the 3-option instead of the 2-option condition because the points remaining in the 2-option condition using the simplistic strategy was less (78).

On each trial, participants will be shown the date and the day with either the deterministic forecast (e.g., “The weather forecast predicts 6 inches of snow for tomorrow”) or the single value forecast and a probabilistic forecast (e.g., “There is 26% chance that the snow accumulation will be greater than 6 inches.”) depending on the condition. In the 3-option probabilistic condition, participants will receive two forecasts, representing the thresholds for delaying one hour (X% chance of greater than 1 inch) or closing school (X% chance of greater than 6 inches). In the 2-option probabilistic condition only the probability of 6 or more inches will be provided. Then participants will be asked to provide their best estimate for the number of inches of snow they expect the next day, the least and the greatest number of inches of snow that would not surprise them, and to rate how much they trust the forecast using a 6-point drop-down menu ranging from “Not at all” to “Completely”. These questions will serve to encourage participants to deliberately process the forecasts and test whether they understood the task correctly. 

After responding to these questions, participants will make their decisions. The weather forecast will remain on the screen for reference. After participants make the decision, they will be shown how many inches of snow accumulation was observed the next day and be informed of the cost or penalty that may have occurred depending on their decisions. Participants, then, will rate their trust in the forecast and move to the next trial. The current balance of points will be present throughout the entire trial.
 
After the 30th trial (halfway through the trial sequence) and at the end, participants will be asked how challenging the task was and respond using a 6-point drop-down menu ranging from “Not at all” to “Completely”. These questions are measured to check whether the 3-option condition is actually perceived to be more cognitively challenging than the 2-option condition.

q13.value: The number of participants will be around 160 (40 participants per condition).

q14.value: Running the power analysis with alpha = 0.05, 85% power, and a medium effect size of 0.5, the estimated sample, the sample needed is 40 in each group.

question.value:
It will be 2 by 2 between-subject design, and a participant will be assigned to one of the four conditions. 
a.	Forecast format (deterministic, probabilistic)
Participants in deterministic forecast conditions will be given deterministic forecasts (a single value estimate of snow accumulation.
Participants in probabilistic forecast conditions will be given probabilistic forecasts (percent chance for a certain amount of snow accumulation) in addition to the deterministic forecast. 
b.	Number of options (2-option, 3-option)
Participants in 2-option conditions will be given 2 options of closing the school and staying open. 
Participants in 3-option conditions will be given 3 options of closing the school, delaying 1 hour, and staying open.

a.	Challengingness (6-point scale from “not at all,” to “a little,” “somewhat,” “quite a bit,” “very much,” and “completely”)

b.	Final point balance

c.	The expected value of decision.  For the 3-option condition, on trials in which the participant advised closing, the -2 point cost will be assigned. 
When the participant advised delaying, the expected value will be calculated by multiplying the -8 point penalty by the probability for 6+ inches on that trial. The product will be added to the -1 point cost to delay. 
When the participant advised staying open, the expected value will be calculated by adding the product of -8 point penalty and the probability for 6+ inches to the product of -2 point penalty and probability for 1+ inches to 6+ inches (calculated by subtracting the probability of 6+ from the probability of 1+ inches). 
For the 2-option condition on trials when the participant advised closing, the -2 point close cost will be assigned.
When the participant advised staying open, the expected value will be calculated by multiplying the -8 point penalty by the probability for 6+ inches. 

d.	Mean Trust rating (6-point scale from “not at all,” to “a little,” “somewhat,” “quite a bit,” “very much,” and “completely”)

e.	Mean snow accumulation estimates (inches of snow participant estimates after seeing forecasts)

a. Challengingness
It will be measured 3 times per participant.  
The three measures will be compared, and if they are not different from each other, the mean of the scores will be used for analysis.

b. Final point balance
It will be used as is.

c. Expected value of decision
For the 3-option condition, on trials in which the participant advised closing, the -2 point cost will be assigned. 
When the participant advised delaying, the expected value will be calculated by multiplying the -8 point penalty by the probability for 6+ inches on that trial. The product will be added to the -1 point cost to delay. 
When the participant advised staying open, the expected value will be calculated by adding the product of -8 point penalty and the probability for 6+ inches to the product of -2 point penalty and probability for 1+ inches to 6+ inches (calculated by subtracting the probability of 6+ from the probability of 1+ inches). 
For the 2-option condition on trials when the participant advised closing, the -2 point close cost will be assigned.
When the participant advised staying open, the expected value will be calculated by multiplying the -8 point penalty by the probability for 6+ inches.

d. Mean Trust rating (6-point scale from “not at all,” to “a little,” “somewhat,” “quite a bit,” “very much,” and “completely”)
Trust rating measured at the end will be used separately as is. The mean scores will be used for trust rating measured before making a decision and the trust rating measured after outcome.

e. Mean snow accumulation estimate.
The mean of estimates for the least amount of snow and the mean of estimates for the maximum amount of snow will be compared.

Challengingness analysis
  Prior to the main analysis, two mixed ANOVA will be conducted to see if the challengingness is constant or not for 3 different measures(in the beginning, in the middle, and at the end). First mixed ANOVA will consist of the number of options as a between-subject variable and challengingness measure as the within-subject variable. The other mixed ANOVA will consist of the forecast format as a between-subject variable and chalengingness measure as the within-subject variable. If they are not different from each other, they will be combined to perform the rest of the challengingness analysis. If they are different from each other, they will be analyzed separately. 
	To determine whether or not the 3-option condition is perceived to be more challenging than 2-option condition, and the probabilistic is more challenging than the deterministic, a two-way analysis of variance will be conducted on the challenging rating with number of options and forecast format as the independent variables. 
	H1a: Forecast format 
This hypothesis will be supported if the mean challenging rating for the probabilistic forecast conditions is significantly higher than that of deterministic forecast conditions. 
	H1b: Number of options 
This hypothesis will be supported if the mean challenging rating for 3-option conditions is significantly higher than that of 2-option conditions.
	H1c: Interaction 
This hypothesis will be supported if the difference in challengingness rating between the probabilistic and deterministic conditions is greater in the 3-option condition than the 2-option condition.
	H1d: Number of options (rating taken before first decision)
This hypothesis will be supported if the mean challenging rating for 3-option condition is significantly higher than that of 2-option conditions.
	H1e: Forecast format (rating taken before first decision)
This hypothesis will be supported if the mean challenging rating for probabilistic forecast condition is significantly higher than that of deterministic forecast condition. 
Decision quality analysis
	To determine whether the decision quality is better with probabilistic than deterministic forecasts and 2 than 3 options two two-way analyses of variance will be conducted on final balance and on expected value. 
	H2a: Forecast format with points
This hypothesis will be supported if the mean final balance of probabilistic forecast conditions is significantly higher than that of deterministic only conditions.
	H2b: Number of options with points
This hypothesis will be supported if the mean final point balance of 2-option condition is significantly higher than that of 3-option conditions.
	H2c: Interaction
This hypothesis will be supported if the interaction effect is significant such that the advantage of the probabilistic over the deterministic forecast is smaller in the 3-option than in the 2-option condition.  
H3a: Forecast format with expected value
This hypothesis will be supported the mean expected value of probabilistic forecast conditions is significantly higher than that of deterministic only conditions.
	H3b: Number of options with expected value
This hypothesis will be supported if we find the mean expected value of 2-option condition is significantly higher than that of 3-option conditions.
	H3c: Interaction
This hypothesis will be supported if the interaction effect is significant such that the advantage of the probabilistic over the deterministic forecast is smaller in the 3-option than in the 2-option condition.  

	
Trust
To determine whether the trust rating for probabilistic forecast is higher than for deterministic forecast after all trials, before making decision, and after the outcome has been shown, two-way analysis of variance will be conducted on mean trust rating. 

H4a: Forecast format 
This hypothesis will be supported if we find the mean trust ratings (before making a decisions, after outcome, and at the end) to be significantly higher in probabilistic forecast conditions than in deterministic forecast only conditions. 
H4b: Number of options 
This hypothesis will be supported if we find the mean trust ratings (before making a decisions, after outcome, and at the end) at the end to be significantly lower in 3-option conditions than in 2-option conditions. 
H4c: Interaction 
This hypothesis will be supported in the interaction effect is significant such that the advantage of the probabilistic over the deterministic forecast is smaller in 3-option than in the 2-option condition.

q22.value: Prior to conducting the main analyses, data of participants who did not understand the task or pay attention will be excluded. The exclusion process will be done by finding the difference of average upper bound snow accumulation estimates and average lower bound snow accumulation estimates for each participant. Participants with negative average difference values, suggesting they provided a lower estimate for the “as much as” question than for the “as little as” question.
